options.text: Trust your inner sense of what feels right
Feel unsettled, but see it as proof of your freedom
Accept uncertainty is unavoidable and still move forward
Question who defined the situation in the first place
Look at how your choices affect others involved
Harmony with your natural self
Responsibility: your choices define you
Creating meaning through action without guarantees
Revealing hidden structures behind what we take for granted
Becoming oneself while recognizing social constraints

questions.question: What best describes freedom to you?

options.text: Living according to one's true nature
Bearing the weight of one's choices
Choosing despite uncertainty or absurdity
Understanding limits imposed by power
Negotiating freedom within real social conditions

questions.question: When facing injustice, your instinct is to...

options.text: Appeal to shared moral values
Take responsibility and act, even alone
Resist, even if the outcome is uncertain
Expose the systems that produce it
Ask who is affected differently and why

questions.question: Which sentence feels closest to your mindset?

options.text: We lose ourselves when we drift away from nature.
I am responsible for what I make of myself.
The world may be absurd, but I still choose to act.
What we call truth is shaped by power.
Freedom must be understood within real conditions.

questions.question: What do you trust most when searching for truth?

options.text: Moral intuition / sentiment
Personal commitment and honesty in choice
Clear-sightedness, even if there's no final answer
Critique: who benefits from this truth?
Shared inquiry and responsibility to others
Rules should align with human nature
Rules don't excuse me: I choose anyway
Rules are there, but I can resist and act
Rules are tools of normalization and control
Rules must be judged by real consequences for people

questions.question: What's the biggest danger in modern society?

options.text: Losing authenticity and the natural self
Hiding behind excuses and bad faith
Giving up and surrendering to nihilism
Invisible control: norms, surveillance, truth regimes
Inequality of lived conditions and constrained freedom

questions.question: When you look at society, you focus first on...

options.text: The moral character of citizens
The individual as author of their life
The human ability to stand up again
Institutions, discourse, and hidden mechanisms
Social roles, dependence, and who bears the burden
Return to what feels genuinely human
Choose, commit, assume the consequences
Stay lucid, keep moving, refuse despair
Analyze power, resist what shapes you silently
Act ethically within real constraints, for real people
